questions.text: A patient with swelling foot, pus discharge, multiple sinuses. KOH smear shows filamentous structures. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Madura mycosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteomyelitis. Presenting complaints are Fever (>38.3˚C), swelling of the limb, pain, systemic symptoms and increased levels of total leucocyte counts, ESR and CRP. Blood Culture is positive for staphylococcus aureus in 60% cases.
  • • Option A. Osteomyelitis.
  • • Option C. Anthrax. This commonly presents with non-specific prodromal symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and sweats which progress to dyspnea and ultimately, respiratory failure and hemodynamic collapse. In cutaneous anthrax, the diagnosis is mostly clinical. However, confirmation can be established by the culture of the lesion, serologic testing, or punch biopsy. In inhalation anthrax, CT scanning of the chest is more sensitive. Sputum culture, gram stain, and blood cultures are not helpful in the acute phase.
  • • Option C. Anthrax.
  • • Option D. Actinomycosis. It frequently occurs at an oral, cervical or facial site, usually as a soft tissue swelling, abscess or mass that is often mistaken for neoplasm. Angle of jaw is most commonly involved. Involvement of bone is usually due to adjacent soft tissues. Mandible is most commonly involved. Vertebrae (spreading from lung or gut) or pelvis (spreading from cecum or colon) may also be involved. Infection of an extremity is uncommon. X-ray show cystic areas of bone destruction with concomitant bone formation and bone destruction.
  • • Option D. Actinomycosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male came with swelling of upper end tibia which is surrounded by a rim of reactive bone. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brodie’s Abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Giant cell tumor (GCT). Radiologically, the GCT appears as eccentrically located, subchondral, radiolucent lesions in the epiphysis of the long bones, with well-defined non-sclerotic margins.
  • • Option A. Giant cell tumor (GCT).
  • • Option C. Hyperparathyroidism . Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis. There is generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, presence of brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull.
  • • Option C. Hyperparathyroidism
  • • Option D. Osteomyelitis . 1st change on X-rays is loss of soft tissue planes. 1st bony change is periosteal reaction seen on day 7-10 (2nd week or day 10), solid periosteal reaction. Later, features of bone destruction appear.
  • • Option D. Osteomyelitis

  • • Swelling of upper end tibia seen to be surrounded by a rim of reactive bone radiologically is suggestive of the diagnosis of Brodie’s abscess.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Chronic osteomyelitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients with Ewing sarcoma. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling, suggesting osteomyelitis. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction.
  • • Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • • Option C. Osteosarcoma. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain . Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis; however, only about 25% of patients experience this phenomenon. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance .
  • • Option C. Osteosarcoma.

Swelling and tenderness may also be present around the area of pain. I nitial radiographs are normal early in the course of a stress fracture. They appear to be positive once healing begins to occur (specific but not sensitive). Even after healing has begun to occur, radiographic findings can be subtle and may be easily overlooked.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male complains of fever and pain right hip. On examination, he has swelling in right hip region, flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip and there is mild reduction in movements in right hip region. On X-ray, there is mild increase in medial joint space. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transient synovitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Septic arthritis . Clinically, in septic arthritis, the h ip remains in the position of flexion, abduction and external rotation as this is the position of maximum capacity of joint to accommodate pus. X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swellings. MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction and aspiration of joint will help to confirm the diagnosis by culture and sensitivity and can also help to differentiate from transient synovitis.
  • • Option A. Septic arthritis

  • • Option C. Tubercular hip . Tuberculous arthritis is a rare finding in children. Usually monarticular, it involves primarily the weight-bearing joints and only exceptionally the joints of the upper extremities. Most patients presenting with tuberculous arthritis will present with indolent joint swelling due to synovial hypertrophy. There is warmth and redness accompanying the swelling. Radiologically, there is peri-articular osteoporosis, peripherally located osseous erosion and gradual joint space narrowing.
  • • Option C. Tubercular hip
  • • Option D. Dislocation of hip . Hip dislocation in children is rare. It is generally a result of significant trauma. The key to clinical diagnosis is the abnormal position of the limb, with the inability to move the hip.

Fever, pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the hip are common symptoms of transient synovitis. questions.text: Infection of ulnar bursa is diagnosed by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kanavel's sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Chvostek’s sign. The Chvostek sign is a clinical finding associated with hypocalcemia . This clinical sign refers to a twitch of the facial muscles that occurs when gently tapping an individual's cheek , in front of the ear. The Chvostek sign aims to elicit an atypical reaction of the facial nerve . The pressure caused by the tapping acts as a triggering stimulus for involuntary contractions of the facial muscles ipsilaterally. The sign is considered negative when no contractions of the facial muscles occur after stimulation of the facial nerve.
